summary: The name Leah has biblical roots, and means wild cow in Hebrew.
full_text:
Leah , as described in the Hebrew Bible, is the first of the two concurrent wives of the Hebrew patriarch Jacob and mother of six sons whose descendants became some of the Twelve Tribes of Israel, along with one daughter, Dinah. She was the daughter of Laban and the older sister of Rachel, whom Jacob originally wanted to marry.
^ Meyers, Carol L.; Craven, Toni; Kraemer, Ross Shepard, eds. , Women in Scripture: A Dictionary of Named and Unnamed Women in the Hebrew Bible, the Apocryphal/Deuterocanonical Books, and the New Testament, Grand Rapids, Michigan: William B. Eerdmans Publishing Company, p. 108, ISBN 9780802849625 
^ Hepner, Gershon , Legal Friction: Law, Narrative, and Identity Politics in Biblical Israel, Bern: Peter Lang, p. 422, ISBN 9780820474625 
^ The electronic Pennsylvania Sumerian Dictionary , OCLC 163207721
title: Leah
